description: From Middle English issue, from Old French issue (“an exit, a way out”), feminine past participle of issir (“to exit”), from Latin exeō (“go out, exit”), from prefix ex- (“out”) + eō (“go”).

definitionGroups.group: The action or an instance of flowing or coming out, an outflow, particularly:

entries.meaning: (military, obsolete) A movement of soldiers towards an enemy, a sortie.
(medicine) The outflow of a bodily fluid, particularly (now rare) in abnormal amounts.
examples: The technique minimizes the issue of blood from the incision.

definitionGroups.group: Someone or something that flows out or comes out, particularly:

entries.meaning: (medicine, now rare) The bodily fluid drained through a natural or artificial issue.
(now usually historical or law) Offspring: one's natural child or children.
examples: He died intestate and without issue, so the extended family have all lawyered up.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Progeny: all one's lineal descendants.
examples: Although his own kingdom disappeared, his issue went on to rule a quarter of Europe.

entries.meaning: (figuratively, obsolete) A race of people considered as the descendants of some common ancestor.
(now rare) The produce or income derived from farmland or rental properties.
examples: 3. A conveys to B all right to the real property aforementioned for a term of _____ years, with all said real property's attendant issues, rents, and profits.

entries.meaning: (historical or rare law) Income derived from fines levied by a court or law-enforcement officer; the fines themselves.
(obsolete) The entrails of a slaughtered animal.
(rare and obsolete) Any action or deed performed by a person.
(obsolete) Luck considered as the favor or disfavor of nature, the gods, or God.
(publishing) A single edition of a newspaper or other periodical publication.
examples: Yeah, I just got the June issue of Wombatboy.

entries.meaning: The entire set of some item printed and disseminated during a certain period, particularly (publishing) a single printing of a particular edition of a work when contrasted with other print runs.
examples: The May 1918 issue of US 24-cent stamps became famous when a printer's error inverted its depiction of an airmail plane.

entries.meaning: (figuratively, originally World War I military slang, usually with definite article) The entire set of something; all of something.
examples: The bloody sergeant snaffled our whole issue of booze, dammit.

entries.meaning: (finance) Any financial instrument issued by a company.
examples: The company's issues have included bonds, stocks, and other securities.

entries.meaning: The loan of a book etc. from a library to a patron; all such loans by a given library during a given period.

definitionGroups.group: The means or opportunity by which something flows or comes out, particularly:

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A sewer.

definitionGroups.group: The place where something flows or comes out, an outlet, particularly:

entries.meaning: (obsolete) An exit from a room or building.
examples: How if there were no centre at all, but just one alley after another, and the whole world a labyrinth without end or issue?

entries.meaning: (now rare) A confluence: the mouth of a river; the outlet of a lake or other body of water.

definitionGroups.group: The action or an instance of sending something out, particularly:

entries.meaning: (historical medicine) A small incision, tear, or artificial ulcer, used to drain fluid and usually held open with a pea or other small object.
examples: Issues and fontanels were supposed remedies for joint diseases, pulmonary tuberculosis, and other chronic conditions.

entries.meaning: The production or distribution of something for general use.
examples: Congress delegated the issue of US currency to the Federal Reserve in 1913.

entries.meaning: The distribution of something (particularly rations or standardized provisions) to someone or some group.
examples: The uniform was standard prison issue.

entries.meaning: (finance) The action or an instance of a company selling bonds, stock, or other securities.
examples: The company's stock issue diluted his ownership.

definitionGroups.group: Any question or situation to be resolved, particularly:

entries.meaning: (law) A point of law or fact in dispute or question in a legal action presented for resolution by the court.
examples: The issue before the court is whether participation in a group blog makes the plaintiff a public figure under the relevant statute.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Anything in dispute, an area of disagreement whose resolution is being debated or decided.
examples: For chrissakes, John, don't make an issue out of it. Just sleep on the floor if you want.

entries.meaning: (rare and obsolete) A dispute between two alternatives, a dilemma.

(US, originally psychology, usually in the plural) A psychological or emotional difficulty, (now informal, figurative and usually euphemistic) any problem or concern considered as a vague and intractable difficulty.
examples: She has daddy issues, mommy issues, drug issues, money issues, trust issues, printer issues... I'm just sayin', girl's got issues.

definitionGroups.group: The action or an instance of concluding something, particularly:

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The end of any action or process.
(obsolete) The end of any period of time.

definitionGroups.group: The end result of an event or events, any result or outcome, particularly:

entries.meaning: (now rare) The result of a discussion or negotiation, an agreement.
(obsolete) The result of an investigation or consideration, a conclusion.
(figurative, now rare) The action or an instance of feeling some emotion.
(figurative, now rare) The action or an instance of leaving any state or condition.

verbs.description: issue (third-person singular simple present issues, present participle issuing, simple past and past participle issued)

entries.meaning: To flow out, to proceed from, to come out or from.
examples: The water issued forth from the spring.
The rents issuing from the land permitted him to live as a man of independent means.

entries.meaning: To rush out, to sally forth.
examples: The men issued from the town and attacked the besiegers.

entries.meaning: To extend into, to open onto.
examples: The road issues into the highway.

entries.meaning: To turn out in a certain way, to result in.
examples: But, for Livy, Roman patriotism is overriding, and this issues, of course, in an antiquarian attention to the city's origins.

entries.meaning: (archaic) To end up as, to turn out being, to become as a result.
(law) To come to a point in fact or law on which the parties join issue.
To send out; to put into circulation.
examples: The Federal Reserve issues US dollars.

entries.meaning: To deliver for use.
examples: The prison issued new uniforms for the inmates.

entries.meaning: To deliver by authority.
examples: The court issued a writ of mandamus.
